journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Optimization of abrasive wear performance in aluminium hybrid metal matrix composites using Taguchi–grey relational analysis

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, RVS Faculty of Engineering, India
2Department of Metallurgical Engineering, PSG College of Technology, India
3Mechanical Program, Kahramanmaraş Sütçü İmam University, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: S Dharmalingam, Department of Mechanical Engineering, RVS Faculty of Engineering, Coimbatore 641 402, Tamil Nadu, India. Email: s.dharmalingam@ymail.com

abstract.p: In this study, the Taguchi–grey relational analysis was used for the optimization of hybrid aluminium composites considering multiple quality characteristics of the material and process parameters relevant to two-body abrasive wear behaviour. Hybrid aluminium composites containing alumina and molybdenum disulphide particulates were produced by stir casting method. Volume loss and frictional force were measured using a pin-on-disc apparatus. In this study, applied load, sliding speed and abrasive size were taken as process parameters and percentage of molybdenum disulphide considered as material parameter. An L9 orthogonal array was used for the Taguchi experimental design. Optimum process parameters were determined using the grey relational analysis for multiple performance characteristics such as wear rate and coefficient of friction. Analysis of variance was used to study the impact of individual factors on the wear rate and coefficient of friction. Experimental results showed that two-body abrasive wear performance of the hybrid composites improved under optimal test conditions. Scanning electron microscopy investigations of the worn out specimens were carried out to explain the wear mechanism of the hybrid composites during two-body abrasive wear.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Aluminium metal matrix composites (MMCs) are being increasingly used in aerospace, electronics and automobile sectors due to their attractive characteristics such as high strength, stiffness and wear resistance.1,2 Alumina and silicon carbide are commonly used as reinforcements in MMCs to improve the wear characteristics of the alloy. Recently, a combination of hard ceramic particles, such as alumina and silicon carbide, along with soft reinforcements, such as graphite and molybdenum disulphide, to produce hybrid MMCs is being investigated to further enhance the tribological behaviour of the aluminium alloy.

Limited amount of investigations have been carried on aluminium hybrid composites containing silicon carbide and graphite to study the dry sliding wear performance. Riahi and Alpas3 investigated wear behaviour of A356 aluminium alloy composites reinforced with 10% SiC/4% graphite as well as with 5% alumina/3% graphite produced by stir casting technique. A mild wear regime was observed for the load range 5–420 N and sliding speeds 0.2–3.0 m/s for both the composites. In the mild wear regime, wear of graphitic composites was primarily controlled by the formation of both a tribolayer as well as an oxidized surface layer on the contact surfaces for both types of composites. Guo and Tsao4 studied Al 6061/10% SiC/graphite hybrid composites containing 2, 5 and 8 vol.% of graphite synthesized by the semi-solid powder densification method. Wear test results showed that both hardness and impact energy decreased with an increase in graphite content. Seizure occurred in the case of unreinforced aluminium alloy, but not for Al/SiC and Al/SiC/graphite composites. Friction coefficient decreased as the percentage of graphite in the composites increased. Wear behaviour became more stable as the amount of graphite added increased.

Abrasive wear occurs when a hard rough surface slides across a soft surface, resulting in material loss. Severity of the abrasion is particularly evident in agricultural, automobile, mining, mineral processing and earth moving components. Abrasive wear is commonly classified as two-body and three-body abrasive wear according to the type of contact and the contact environment. Two-body wear occurs when the grits or hard particles remove material from the opposite surface, with material removal occurring by cutting and ploughing action. Three-body wear occurs when the abrasive particles are trapped between surfaces to roll and slide down the surface. Singh et al.5 observed that abrasive wear rate of both composite and matrix alloy increased with increase in applied load and abrasive size in Al–Si12Fe/sillimanite composites. Wear resistance of the composite was superior to that of unreinforced matrix alloy for finer size abrasives, while a reversed trend was observed for coarser abrasives. Wear rate also decreased with increase in the sliding distance for composites due to work hardening of the wear surface. According to Das et al.,6 abrasive wear resistance properties of Al–4.5 wt% Cu alloy improved significantly by the addition of alumina and zircon particles. A decrease in particle size improved the wear resistance for both alumina- and zircon-reinforced composites, since smaller particle reinforced composite has higher hardness and is more efficient in blunting the abrading surface. Zircon-reinforced composite showed better wear resistance than alumina-reinforced composite due to its enhanced particle–matrix bonding. Izciler and Muratoğlu7 concluded that the abrasive wear rates of the Al 2124/silicon carbide composites increased with increasing applied loads. Composites tested with silicon carbide abrasive particles showed higher wear rate than those abraded by Al2O3 abrasive particles due to higher hardness of SiC abrasives. Modi8 observed that Al 2104/alumina composites experienced lower material loss than the unreinforced matrix alloy for all test conditions employed. This lower material loss has been explained as due to work hardening of the matrix as well as the protection given by the dispersoid phase. Yilmaz and Buytoz9 observed that wear rate of Al–0.86Mg–0.46Si–0.15Cu/alumina composites tested for against 125 µm abrasive paper was higher compared to wear rate obtained when tested with 65 µm silicon carbide abrasive paper. Aluminium alloys with larger alumina size are more effective against abrasive wear than those with smaller alumina particulates.

Statistical methods have commonly been used for analysis, prediction and optimization of a number of engineering processes. Such methods enable the investigators to define and study the effect of every single condition possible in an experiment, particularly when numerous factors are involved. A summary of literature review on the statistical methods used for studying the tribological behaviour is presented here. Davim10 studied the tribological behaviour of the brass/steel pair using the Taguchi method. Results showed that temperature as well as the velocity/load and load/temperature interactions had a great influence on the coefficient of friction. Wear was highly influenced by the applied load but only to a smaller extent by temperature. Basavarajappa and Chandramohan11 proposed a Taguchi design of experiments to describe the dry sliding wear behaviour of both Al 2219/15% SiC as well as Al/15% SiC/3% graphite hybrid composites. Empirical linear regression equations were developed for predicting the wear volume loss for a specified set of experimental conditions. These equations demonstrated that Al/SiC/graphite hybrid composite exhibited higher wear resistance compared to Al/SiC composites. Wear volume loss decreased with an increase in the sliding speed, but increased with an increase in applied load and sliding distance for both type of composites. Interaction effect between load and sliding speed was predominant in Al/SiC/Gr-reinforced composites with reference to sliding distance. Sahin and Özdin12 employed a factorial design of experiments to develop linear equations for predicting wear rate of Al/SiC composites. Established equations demonstrated that 10 and 15 wt% SiC composites exhibited higher wear resistance than that of the unreinforced Al 2011 matrix alloy. Wear rate of both unreinforced alloy and composites increased with increasing abrasive size, applied load but decreased with increasing sliding distance. Among the various parameters, abrasive size was found to be more significant, followed by applied load, for the composites. However, for the unreinforced alloy, applied load was a predominant factor, followed by the abrasive size. Interaction of load and abrasive size was found to be more significant for both unreinforced alloy and the composites. Kök13 used the Taguchi method to investigate the abrasive wear behaviour of Al2O3 particle reinforced Al 2024 alloy cast composites under different testing conditions. Results indicated that reinforcement size was found to be the most influencing factor on abrasive wear, followed by abrasive grain size. Wear rate of the composites increased with increasing abrasive grain size and applied load, while it decreased with increasing reinforcement size and sliding distance. Suresha and Sridhara14 investigated the dry sliding wear behaviour of Al–Si7Mg matrix composites reinforced with graphite and 10% SiC particulate. Using central composite design, the effect of percentage of reinforcement, load, sliding speed and sliding distance on stir-cast Al alloy/graphite, Al alloy/SiC composite and Al alloy/SiC/graphite hybrid composites was investigated. Results showed that hybrid composites exhibit better wear characteristics. Sahoo and Pal15 studied the tribological performance of electroless Ni–P coatings and optimized the tribological test parameters using Taguchi method coupled with grey relational analysis (GRA). A grey relational grade obtained from the GRA was used as performance index to study the behaviour of electroless Ni–P coating with respect to friction and wear characteristics.

In this study, GRA and Taguchi orthogonal array have been combined to analyse the experimental results of two-body abrasive wear behaviour of hybrid composites. Analysis was done for Al alloy/10 wt% Al2O3 MMC, Al alloy/10 wt% Al2O3/2 wt% MoS2 and Al alloy/10 wt% Al2O3/4 wt% MoS2 hybrid composites. Control parameters used in the study were applied load, sliding speed, abrasive medium as well as percentage of molybdenum disulphide. Determination of the optimum combinations of these control factors was the main objective. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to find out the contribution of each parameter and its interactions on the abrasive wear behaviour. Worn out surfaces were investigated using the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) to understand the wear mechanisms operating during abrasive wear.

sec.title: Taguchi method and grey relational theory
sec.p: In the Taguchi method, an orthogonal array is used to reduce the number of experiments for finding out the optimum test parameters.16 The orthogonal array provides a smallest possible matrix in which influence of all parameters as well as their interactions are considered simultaneously. In this method, signal-to-noise (S/N) ratio is used to represent a performance characteristic and the largest value of S/N ratio is considered. Based on the objective of the experiment, any one of the S/N ratios, namely lower-the-better, the higher-the-better or the nominal-the-better is selected for further analysis.

Grey system theory developed by Prof. Deng17 has proved to be a useful tool in dealing with poor, incomplete and uncertain information. GRA based on the grey system theory can also be used to solve the complicated interrelationships among the multiple performance characteristics effectively. GRA is used to obtain a grey relational grade to evaluate such multiple performance characteristics. As a result, optimization of complicated multiple performance characteristics can be converted into optimization of a single grey relational grade. The procedure that involved the grey relational method is as follows:
Experimental results are normalized between zero and one.
Grey relational coefficients are calculated from the normalized data. This coefficient helps to distinguish between the desired and actual experimental data.
Grey relational grade is calculated by averaging the grey relational coefficients. Grey relational grade is treated as the overall response of the process instead of the multiple responses of wear rate and coefficient of friction.
ANOVA for the input parameters is calculated with the grey relational grade to find which parameter has a significant influence on the abrasive wear performance as well as its percentage of contribution.
Optimum parameter levels for abrasive wear performance are then selected.
Confirmation experiment is conducted to verify the optimum wear parameters obtained.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: In this study, an Al–Si alloy (Al–Si10Mg) containing hard reinforcement as alumina (Al2O3) particles and soft reinforcement as molybdenum disulphide (MoS2) has been used. The alloy contains 10.65 wt% Si, 0.14 wt% Cu, 0.48 wt% Mg, the rest being aluminium. This matrix alloy is used for intricate, thin-walled castings that demand high strength, such as castings for the automotive industry and general engineering. It exhibits excellent casting characteristics and is suitable for sand casting, gravity die-casting and high-pressure die-casting.

The production process of the composites is as follows: Al–Si10Mg alloy was charged into an electrical resistance heated furnace that was modified for this study. The melting process was carried out under argon atmosphere in a graphite crucible and heated to 1073 K. Mixing of reinforcement was conducted with a graphite impeller by stir casting method with a separate graphite crucible. Pre-heated alumina particles were incorporated into the molten metal and stirring was continued for further 10 min. The molten mixture was then solidified using a cast iron die to produce cylindrical pins of diameter 14 mm and length 75 mm. In this study, Al–Si10Mg MMCs reinforced with 10 wt% alumina is produced. The same procedure was repeated for hybrid MMC with 2 wt% and 4 wt% of molybdenum disulphide with 10 wt% Al2O3 to the aluminium alloy. Hardness of the composite was measured using Vickers microhardness tester with 100 g load at different locations on the surface of the composite. The hybrid composite and wear test specimen are shown in Figure 1. The density and average hardness of the composites are given in Table 1. Figure 1.
Composite and wear test pins.
Table 1.
Density and hardness of the composites.
Composite designation Density (g/cm3) Vickers hardness (VHN)
Al–Si10Mg–10 wt% alumina 2.680 116
Al–Si10Mg–10 wt% alumina–2 wt% molybdenum disulphide 2.682 117
Al–Si10Mg–10 wt% alumina–4 wt% molybdenum disulphide 2.684 114

sec.title: Design of experiments
sec.p:
According to Deuis et al.,18 various factors affect the abrasive wear performance of composites. Based on extensive literature survey and experimental constraints, four control factors were identified for analysis: load (L), sliding speed (S), abrasive size (E) and percentage of MoS2 (M). Wear rate and coefficient of friction were selected as response variables to evaluate the abrasive wear performance of the hybrid MMCs. In the Taguchi method, the selection of orthogonal array is concerned with the total degrees of freedom of the abrasive wear parameters. Degree of freedom is defined as the number of comparisons among the abrasive wear parameters required to optimize each parameter with the selected levels. The degree of freedom for the orthogonal array should be greater than or at least equal to the selected number of control factors. In this study, the degree of freedom required is eight. Hence, an L9 orthogonal array was selected (Table 2). Table 2.
Experimental layout using an L9 orthogonal array.
Experiment no. Abrasive wear parameters
Load, L (N) Speed, S (m/s) Abrasive size, E (mesh) % of MoS2, M (wt%)
1 1 1 1 1
2 1 2 2 2
3 1 3 3 3
4 2 1 2 3
5 2 2 3 1
6 2 3 1 2
7 3 1 3 2
8 3 2 1 3
9 3 3 2 1

sec.title: Two-body abrasive wear testing of composites
sec.p:
A pin-on-disc apparatus (Figure 2) was used to study the abrasive wear behaviour using wear pins, of diameter 10 mm and height 40 mm, obtained from the hybrid composite. These composite pins were subjected to abrasive wear test by rubbing against silicon carbide (SiC) abrasive papers of varying grit sizes (1000, 320 and 120 mesh) fixed to the rotating steel disc. Abrasive tests were conducted by varying loads (20, 40 and 60 N) with varying sliding velocities (0.5, 1.0 and 1.5 m/s) for a constant sliding distance of 250 m. Wear losses of the specimens were measured using an electronic balance of 0.0001 g accuracy. Abrasive wear tests were carried out at room temperature (30℃ ± 3℃, RH 55% ±5%). Control factors and their levels used in this study are given in Table 3. Wear test samples were cleaned with acetone prior to and after testing to remove wear debris. The differences in the weight measured before and after the test gave the abrasive wear loss of the composites which were subsequently converted into volume loss. Tangential forces on the specimens were obtained from the load cell fitted to the pin-on-disc apparatus. Wear rate and coefficient of friction were calculated from the wear data obtained. Equations (1) to (3) are used for calculating volume loss, wear rate and coefficient of friction (1)Volume loss=m1-m2ρ×1000mm3 (2)Wear rate=VLmm3/m (3)Coefficient of friction,μ=FTFN where m1 is the mass of the specimen before the wear test, m2 the mass of the specimen after the wear test, ρ the density of the composite in g/cm3, V the volume loss in mm3 and L the applied load in newton. The coefficient of friction is calculated by the ratio between the tangential forces (FT) and the normal force (FN). The tangential force is obtained from the load cell fitted on the pin-on-disc apparatus. Figure 2.
Pin-on-disc apparatus used for wear studies.
Table 3.
Abrasive wear parameters and their levels.
Abrasive wear parameters Levels
1 2 3
Applied load, L (N) 20 40 60
Sliding speed, S (m/s) 0.5 1 1.5
Abrasive size, E (mesh) 1000 320 120
% of MoS2, M (wt%) 0 2 4

Based on the Taguchi orthogonal array, the experiments were conducted and results are given in Table 4. Table 4.

1 20 0.5 1000 0 0.070 0.604
2 20 1 320 2 0.272 0.584
3 20 1.5 120 4 0.410 0.550

8 60 1 1000 4 0.133 0.700

sec.title: Data pre-processing
sec.p: GRA depends on the quality characteristics of a data sequence. Experimental results (wear rate and coefficient of friction) were normalized in the range between zero and one based on the quality characteristics of the responses using equations (4) to (7). In a given series of data, for the larger-the-better characteristic, the original sequence is normalized as follows (4)xi*(k)=xio(k)-minxio(k)maxxio(k)-minxio(k)
In the case of smaller-the-better characteristic, the original data are normalized as follows (5)xi*(k)=maxxio(k)-xio(k)maxxio(k)-minxio(k)
For the nominal-the-best characteristic, the data are normalized as follows (6)xi*(k)=1-|xio(k)-xo|maxxio(k)-xo

Or, the values of the original sequence are divided by the first value of the sequence (7)xi*(k)=xio(k)xio(1) where i = 1, … , m; k = 1, … , n; m is the number of experimental data items and n the number of parameters. The term xio(k) denotes the original sequence, xi*(k) the sequence after the data pre-processing, max xio(k) the largest value of xio(k), min xio(k) the smallest value of xio(k) and xo the desired value. The deviation sequences Δoi(k), Δmax(k) and Δmin(k) for i = 1–9 and k = 1–3 are also calculated.

sec.title: Grey relational coefficient and grey relational grade
sec.p: After data pre-processing, the grey relational coefficient ξi(k) for the kth performance characteristics in the ith experiment is calculated as (8)ξi(k)=Δmin+ζΔmaxΔoi(k)+ζΔmax where 0<ξi(k)≤1; Δoi= |xo*(k)-xi*(k) |; Δmin=min∀j∈imin∀k |xo*(k)-xj*(k) |; and Δmax=max∀j∈imax∀k |xo*(k)-xj*(k) |. Reference sequence is denoted by xo*(k) and xi*(k) the comparability sequence; ζ is the distinguishing coefficient, which is defined in the range 0≤ζ≤1. Normally, ζ is taken as 0.5. The average value of the grey relational coefficients is the grey relational grade. Therefore, the grey relational grade is defined as follows (9)γi=1n∑k=1nξi(k)

The grey relational grade γi represents the correlation between the reference sequence and the comparability sequence which has higher grey relational grade. Table 5 lists the calculated grey relational grade for each experiment in the L9 orthogonal array. A higher grey relational grade implies that the corresponding parameter combination is closer to the optimum. Table 5.
Calculated grey relational grades and their ranks.
Experiment no. Grey relational grade Rank
2 0.591 5
3 0.592 4
4 0.486 7
5 0.470 8
6 0.893 1
7 0.395 9
8 0.713 3
9 0.549 6

sec.title: Effect of abrasive wear parameters on wear rate and coefficient of friction
sec.p:
The initial optimum conditions of these control factors determined from Figure 3(a) are load (20 N), sliding speed (1.5 m/s) and abrasive medium (1000 mesh) for wear rate and denoted as (L1-S3-E1-M1). From Figure 3(b), it can be observed that L1-S3-E1-M1 is the lowest value of the coefficient of friction achieved with a load of 20 N, sliding speed 1.5 m/s and abrasive medium 1000 mesh. The dotted line in the figures indicates the average value of responses. Figure 3.
Effects of abrasive wear parameters on multiple responses: (a) wear rate and (b) coefficient of friction.

Response table of Taguchi–grey relational method was used to calculate the values of the average grey relational grade (Table 6). The order of factors for minimizing the abrasive wear performance is abrasive medium (E), load (L), sliding speed (S) and molybdenum disulphide percentage (M). Figure 4 shows the mean value of grey relational grade for different levels of each of the abrasive wear parameters. Larger the grey relational grade, the better are the multiple performance characteristics. The optimum condition for the tested samples becomes L1-S3-E1-M2 for the main control factors, namely load (20 N), sliding speed (1.5 m/s), abrasive medium (1000 mesh) and molybdenum disulphide percentage (2 wt%), as observed from the response table. Thus, it can be concluded that Al alloy/10 wt% Al2O3/2 wt% MoS2 composites are more effective than Al alloy/10 wt% Al2O3/4 wt% MoS2 composites for abrasive wear condition. Figure 4.
Effect of abrasive wear parameters in terms of grey relational grade.
Table 6.
Response table for grey relational grade.
Level Load (L) Sliding speed (S) Abrasive size (E) Molybdenum disulphide % (M)
1 0.6665* 0.5656 0.8075* 0.6119
2 0.6164 0.5914 0.5417 0.6263*
3 0.5521 0.6780* 0.4858 0.5968
Maximum–minimum 0.1144 0.1125 0.3217 0.0294
Rank 2 3 1 4
Average grey relational grade = 0.6117.

sec.title: Analysis of variance
sec.p:
Table 7 presents the ANOVA results for wear rate and it can be observed that the abrasive medium with 92.7515% of contribution is the most significant parameter controlling the abrasive wear. Load comes next with 4.0533%, followed by sliding speed with 1.8397% and molybdenum disulphide percentage with 1.3555% for the minimization of the wear rate. Load with 73.5873% of contribution is the most significant control parameter for coefficient of friction, followed by sliding speed with 21.6112%, molybdenum disulphide percentage with 1.5052% and abrasive medium with 3.2964%. Table 7.

MoS2 percentage (M) 0.0066 2 0.0033 1.3555

Coefficient of friction
Load (L) 0.2634 2 0.1317 73.5873
Sliding speed (S) 0.0773 2 0.0387 21.6112
Abrasive medium (E) 0.0118 2 0.0059 3.2964
MoS2 percentage (M) 0.0054 2 0.0027 1.5052

Table 8 presents the results of the ANOVA for the combined response of the wear rate and coefficient of friction using the calculated values from the grey relational grade. From the table, abrasive medium with 80.1733% of contribution is the most significant control parameter for the abrasive wear. Load with 9.8247%, sliding speed with 9.4146%, and molybdenum disulphide percentage with 0.5874% of contribution follow abrasive medium when minimization of the wear rate and coefficient of friction are considered simultaneously. sec.title: Confirmation experiment
sec.p:
Optimum values of the abrasive wear parameters obtained were correlated with the SEM micrographs of the worn surface of aluminium hybrid MMC specimens. Confirmation test was conducted to check the accuracy of the analysis for Al alloy/10 wt% Al2O3/MoS2 hybrid composite at 20 N load, 1.5 m/s sliding speed, 1000 mesh size abrasive medium and 2 wt% MoS2 percentage. The results obtained by the confirmation experiment were: 0.0344 mm3/m for wear rate and 0.536 for coefficient of friction. The formation of fine grooves on the surface is clearly shown in Figure 5(a). However, under worst conditions, Al alloy/10 wt% Al2O3/4% MoS2 at applied load 60 N and sliding speed 0.5 m/s on the 120 mesh abrasive paper shows deeper grooves as well as delamination on the composites (Figure 5(b)). The results obtained under these conditions are wear rate 0.6392 mm3/m and coefficient of friction 0.780. Figure 5.
Worn surface at: (a) best condition and (b) worst condition.

sec.title: Discussion on abrasive wear behaviour of Al alloy/alumina/molybdenum disulphide hybrid MMCs
sec.p: Investigations on the effect of load, sliding speed, abrasive size and percentage of MoS2 during abrasive wear of Al/10 wt% Al2O3 composites with 2 wt% and 4 wt% MoS2 hybrid composites were carried out to study the abrasive wear behaviour of these composites. As in the case of dry sliding wear of Al/Al2O3/MoS2 composites, additional abrasive wear tests were conducted for confirmation using SEM investigations.

sec.title: Effect of load
sec.p:
As the load is applied to the specimen during the abrasive wear test, abrasive particles make contact with the composite surface and pierce it. Abrasive wear progresses by the grooving action of these particles. The penetrating abrasive is subjected to rotary motion on the composite specimen surface, forming wear grooves. These grooves are created due to plastic flow of materials caused either by the cutting or ploughing action of the abrasive particles. Figure 6 shows that at a higher applied load (40 N) in Al/10 wt% Al2O3/2 wt% MoS2 composite, severe plastic deformation occurs on the surface of the ductile matrix; hence, the material from the wear surface is removed by the ploughing action. In this case, large flakes are generated and retained along the side of the wear track for a long duration. Due to heating, these flakes are subjected to severe plastic deformation and spread over the wear surface. Figure 6.
Worn surfaces of Al alloy/10 wt% Al2O3/2%MoS2 composite at a sliding speed of 1 m/s on 120 mesh abrasives at an applied load of 40 N.

sec.title: Effect of sliding speed
sec.p:
With an increase in the sliding speed during the abrasive wear test, momentum transfer in the normal direction increases the upward force on the pin surface due to rotational inertia. When sliding speed is increased, the travel time to complete the required sliding distance (250 m) is decreased; thus, the generation of wear debris is significantly reduced, resulting in decrease in wear rate of the composites. This results in an increased separation between the composite and the abrasive surface. Hence, at high sliding speeds, plastic deformation becomes more difficult, leading to less extensive surface damage compared to lower sliding speeds. Figure 7 shows cutting of the surface of Al/10 wt% Al2O3/4 wt% MoS2 composite by the abrasive particles at a higher sliding speed (1 m/s). Abrasive particle cracking increased at higher sliding speeds, leading to third-body abrasive action between the composite and the disc surfaces with resulting increase in cracking and removal of abrasive particles from the emery paper. This was due to decreasing cutting efficiency of the abrasive particles as well as the blunting of the sharp edges of the abrasives. Figure 7.
Worn surface of Al alloy/10 wt% Al2O3/4 wt%MoS2 composite at 40 N load on 120 mesh abrasives at a sliding speed of 1 m/s.

Decrease in coefficient of friction with sliding speed promoted development of low shear strength tribofilms on the rubbing surfaces due to increasing surface temperature at the contact surface. At lower sliding speeds, a protective tribolayer that formed on the surfaces of the composites was responsible for the lower frictional values. Rapid formation of tribolayer coverage at higher speeds tends to lower surface hardness of the composites for a fixed sliding distance. Hence, coefficient of friction decreases with sliding speed, due to decrease in contact time of the abrasive particles, and thus, the intensity of the tangential forces decreases with the sliding speed.

sec.title: Effect of abrasive size
sec.p:
Wear rate depends on the w/r ratio, where w is the groove width and r the radius of the spherical tip of the abrasive particle. Radius of the abrasive tip varies with abrasive size, while the width of the groove increases with increase in abrasive size, as observed from the SEM image (Figure 8). The w/r ratio increases with an increase in applied load, since ‘r’ remains constant for fixed abrasive size. In case of the composites, alumina reinforcement acts as a barrier against the penetration and movement of SiC abrasives at lower loads. Figure 8.
Worn surface of Al alloy/10 wt% Al2O3/4 wt%MoS2 composite at 40 N load at a sliding speed of 1 m/s with abrasive size of 320 mesh.

As a result, w/r ratio may not change significantly with applied load when the applied load is in the lower range. This has been confirmed by Sin et al.19 With passage of time, these abrasive particles get degraded, particularly the finer abrasive particles at higher applied loads. Thus, the cutting efficiency of such abrasive is reduced after the wear test, as shown in Figure 9. Wear rate is largely independent of the abrasive grit size.20 With larger abrasive particles, abrasive particle contact area is smaller and the stresses that are developed for the same applied load are higher. Hence, for a fixed load, the effective stress on the individual abrasive particles is more for coarser abrasive particles, since the load is shared by lesser number of abrasives. In addition, if abrasive particles are finer, the surface contact with the material is elastic in nature at lower loads, and hence, it will support the load without material removal. However, as the load is increased, abrasives make plastic contact with the composite surface, causing more surface damage even for finer abrasive sizes. Coarser abrasives plough more deeply into the composites and hence break easily. This may be attributed to the fact that coarser abrasives are stronger than the finer ones and experience higher effective stress even at lower applied loads. As a result, the surface is subjected to higher plastic deformation even at lower applied loads for coarser abrasives. With coarser abrasive size and higher applied loads, width of the wear grooves as well as surface cracking increase significantly. Due to a relatively higher effective stress and higher level of frictional heating at the surface, material removal by cutting and ploughing increases. Abrasive grits have different negative rake angles, and depending upon the rake angles, the wear rate will change. Due to these factors, the abrasives influence the wear rate of the composites significantly. Figure 9.
SEM micrograph of 320 mesh abrasive paper after wear test of 40 N load and sliding speed of 0.5 m/s.

sec.title: Effect of alumina and molybdenum disulphide content
sec.p:
Alumina reinforcement improves the load-bearing capacity and thermal stability of the composites. Alumina helps to reduce material adhesion to the abrasive paper surface and hence leads to reduced wear rate of composites. When a load is applied to the composite, a stress concentration occurs around the hard reinforcement. Applied load and hardness of materials are the most important factors affecting the abrasion process.21 When the load is applied, the depth to which the abrasive particles penetrate into the specimen surface depends on the type and inter-particle distance of reinforcement in the composite. If the surface has no reinforcement, the abrasive will not get to have any obstacle to prevent its penetration into the composite. Increase in wear rate as well as depth of penetration causes high amount of material removal during abrasion tests of unreinforced alloys. A uniform distribution of the reinforcements along with smaller inter-particle distance in composites will lead to better wear resistance. The depth and width of the grooves as well as the number of grooves on the composite surface depends upon on the size, shape and rake angle of the abrasives and composite surface characteristics. Material removal in the composites proceeds by the removal of alumina and growth of microcracks. Craters formed on the material surface (due to ploughing action of the abrasive grit) were trapped and underwent rotation between the counter face and the specimen. SEM micrograph (Figure 10) shows the formation of all MoS2 lubrication layers, wear debris and surface cracks. Alumina particles on the composite surface reduce the severity of the micro-ploughing action of the abrasive particles (due to their interaction with the abrasive grit) and result in a decreased wear rate. Figure 10.
Worn surface of Al alloy/10% Al2O3/2% MoS2 tested at 60 N load at a sliding speed of 0.5 m/s with 120 mesh abrasive size.

Silicon carbide abrasive particles penetrate into the composite surface and interact with the Al2O3 particles and MoS2 during the rotary motion. During this process, Al2O3 and MoS2 particles may be pulled out from the matrix by the abrasive particles or it may undergo degradation. Depth of penetration of the abrasives into the specimen surface is a function of several factors such effective stress level, abrasive size, rake angle of abrasive tips and hardness of the specimen surface. The depth of penetration increases with increasing abrasive size and applied load, while it decreases with increasing the surface hardness of the material.5 In comparison to Al–Si10Mg/10% Al2O3/2 wt% MoS2 composite, Al–Si10Mg/10% Al2O3/4 wt% MoS2 composite exhibits higher wear rates with increasing load and abrasive size. This is because of the relatively lower hardness of the composite which causes the abrasive to penetrate to a greater depth. The depth of the grooves formed due to penetration depends on the hardness of the composites. Plastic deformation of the composite gives rise to the possibility of brittle alumina particles fracturing under severe wear conditions and their subsequent pull out from the matrix at both higher loads as well as during contact with coarser abrasive size during rotary motion. These wear debris particles act as a third body and may lead to increase wear of the composites.

Sahin and Özdin12 observed that wear rate of the matrix as well as the composites increased with increasing abrasive size and applied load, while it decreased with sliding distance and applied load. Yilmaz22 observed that with increase in hardness due to reinforcement content, the wear rate of Al2024/SiCrFe, CrFeC and Al2O3 composites decreased during abrasive wear tests. From the above factors, it can be concluded that with increasing MoS2 content, the hardness of the composite decreases due to bonding of matrix alloy and alumina with MoS2. A decrease in wear rate is observed in the case of 2 wt% MoS2 composite compared to 4 wt% MoS2 composite specimens.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The primary results from this study provides an insight into abrasive wear performance of hybrid aluminium MMCs and discuss the effect of various process parameters such as applied load, sliding speed, abrasive size and percentage of molybdenum disulphide content on abrasive wear. The results can be abridged as follows:
Minimum wear rate and coefficient of friction were found to be the optimal parameter combination of the abrasive wear at an applied load of 20 N, sliding speed 1.5 m/s and abrasive medium 1000 mesh and 2 wt% MoS2.
Thus, combined response of wear rate and coefficient of friction, applied load (9.8247%), sliding speed (9.4146%), abrasive medium (80.1733%) and molybdenum disulphide percentage (0.5874%) exerts a significant influence on the abrasive wear of the aluminium hybrid composites.
Grooving, ploughing and micro-cutting along with fracture and delamination during abrasive wear of the composite surfaces were confirmed using SEM analysis.
Wear rate decreased with increase in sliding speed and molybdenum disulphide content, but increased with load and abrasive size.
Coefficient of friction increased with load but decreased with increase in sliding speed and molybdenum disulphide content.
Hybrid aluminium composites with 10 wt% Al2O3 with 2 wt% MoS2 hybrid MMCs gave the best wear performance for the optimized abrasive wear parameters obtained.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
